title: Hidden tunnels to Knights Templar warrior monks' 'treasure tower' found in Israel

A team of archaeologists have achieved their dream of unearthing the legendary hidden tunnels of the ancient warrior monks of the Knights Templar.

Described as "the stuff of childhood dreams", archaeologists working in the historic coastal city of Acre in Israel have discovered the underground network used to move vast amounts of gold during the medieval era.

American explorer Dr Albert Lin said: "During the Crusades the Knights Templar battle for God, gold and glory. Somewhere in the modern city of Acre lies their command centre, and possibly their treasure.

"It’s the stuff of childhood dreams. I’m here to find them."

The Knights Templar fought in the crusades that began in the 11th century. They were devout Christians who fought bloody battles in the Holy Land and protected Europeans who travelled to the conquered lands.

(Image: National Geographic)

(Image: National Geographic)

They became rich from treasure during the Crusades and this loot became legend after the group died out in the 14th century.

Acre in Israel is a setting rich in history and has now been found to hold the tunnels which Dr Lin's team say were used to move tonnes of gold from the port to a fortress - their 'treasure tower'.

And Dr Lin believes his team has unearthed the site for the very first time.

Dr Lin said: "The Templar's hidden tunnels snaked beneath the streets.

(Image: National Geographic)

(Image: National Geographic)

"They secretly transported gold to the Acre fortress' crowning glory, its treasure tower.

"The full magnificence of Acre's fortress was preserved for those arriving by sea.

"Its mighty sea defences and lookout towers stood against any invader."

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

(Image: Getty Images)

The discovery was unveiled to the world in a new National Geographic Documentary, aired on Sunday, called 'Lost Cities with Albert Lin'.

Dr Lin's team used LiDAR laser technology, which allows archaeologists to scan deep into the ground without causing any damage.

They scanned the location in the ancient port city of Acre - now a modern city - where the Knights Templar had key headquarters in the Third Crusade. The scans also found a guard house.

(Image: National Geographic)

And using the latest 3D modelling technology, they have managed to bring the fortress back to life with images showing how it would have looked.

The tower is buried beneath the rocky ground and there's no firm plans to excavate the site.
description: A team of archaeologists in Acre in Israel have revealed the discovery of hidden tunnels used to carry gold and treasure to the Knights Templar fortress during the Crusades
